item.title: Eddie McGuire gone: Seven crushes Nine's Footy Show for 2019 - Crikey
item.description:
Eddie McGuire gone: Seven crushes Nine's Footy Show for 2019  Crikey

After nearly two decades, Seven has the upper hand in the ongoing footy show contest. What will Nine offer next year to come back from this?

The future of The Footy Show has been decided, with the Channel 9 program set for a makeover in 2019.

item.title: Footy Show replaced by new weekly Channel 9 football program - The Advertiser
item.description:
Footy Show replaced by new weekly Channel 9 football program  The Advertiser

The iconic AFL panel show will be knocked down and re-built from scratch to create an entirely new concept for 2019. Host Eddie McGuire made the ...

item.title: Nine to shake up AFL Footy Show plans in 2019 - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Nine to shake up AFL Footy Show plans in 2019  mUmBRELLA*

Nine’s AFL Footy Show host, Eddie McGuire, has revealed a number of changes to the network’s AFL offering for 2019. McGuire, who announced the news on his radio show, Triple M Hot Breakfast, first hosted the program when it launched in 1994. McGuire announced he would no longer host the weekly AFL Footy Show He later took an 11 year hiatus from the program, before announcing his return in July last year. Today, McGuire said he will no longer host a weekly program, instead running a number of ‘specials’ alongside Sam Newman next year. “We are going to just change it up a bit next year,” McGu...

item.title: Why Sam turned down ‘I’m a Celebrity …’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Why Sam turned down ‘I’m a Celebrity …’  The Advertiser

He’s not going anywhere. But don’t expect him lobbing into the jungle with Ten either. The Footy Show scallywag known as “The Fossil” or “Foss” confirmed to The Herald Sun he had signed with Nine for at least two more years. INSIDERS: HOW THE FOOTY SHOW RATINGS TUMBLED BAD BLOW: FOOTY SHOW RATINGS CRASH TO ALL-TIME LOW MOVING ON: LONG-TIME MEMBER LEAVES FOOTY SHOW “I am very pleased to be continuing on with the network,” Newman said. “I’ll be there for the foreseeable future and I’m very pleased to be on board again. It’s business as usual.” Newman, 72, has agreed to a new multi-year exclus...

item.title: The Karl conundrum - The Australian
item.description:
The Karl conundrum  The Australian

A veritable who’s who of the Nine Entertainment Co’s on-air personalities, past and present, took over top chef Luke Mangan’s fashionable Sydney inner-city eatery last week to celebrate the 40th birthday of current affairs icon 60 Minutes. But one notable no-show for the big event did not go unnoticed by the assembled glitterati: that of Nine’s highest profile star and regular 60 Minutes contributor, Karl Stefanovic. Stefanovic may not have been physically present, but, as has ­become customary at Nine over the past couple of years, the Today co-host was the elephant in the high-powered roo...

item.title: Collingwood extends Buckley's deal despite again missing out on AFL finals - ABC News
item.description:
Collingwood extends Buckley's deal despite again missing out on AFL finals  ABC News

Collingwood has handed under-fire coach Nathan Buckley a new two-year contract despite again failing to reach the AFL finals. Buckley has been Collingwood mentor since 2012, but the Magpies have not made the AFL top eight since 2013. Buckley's coaching record - Games coached: 136 - Wins: 70 - Losses: 65 - Draws: 1 - Win ratio: 51.47% "I'm rapt to be supported in the role. I woke up this morning to the news and I was suitably humbled and a little bit nervous, to be honest. I've always had a really strong understanding of what's going to happen and how it needs to be," Buckley told the media....

item.title: Eddie McGuire kicks off the new lookAFL Footy Show - The Advertiser
item.description:
Eddie McGuire kicks off the new lookAFL Footy Show  The Advertiser

Former AFL Footy Show host Eddie McGuire is back to front the new look show. Courtesy: Nine Network

item.title: Football fans to get more McGuire - The Australian
item.description:
Football fans to get more McGuire  The Australian

The Magpies are in the midst of a review regarding their business model, which includes ­examinations of their football and netball departments. Coach Nathan Buckley’s tenure is in peril, with the Magpies sitting 14th ahead tomorrow’s clash against West Coast at Etihad Stadium. But McGuire, who earlier this week defended his long-running presidency of Austra­lia’s biggest football club, will also be tasked with rescuing the flagging AFL show. He will replace Melbourne journalist Craig Hutchison, whose tenure co-hosting with Rebecca Maddern proved short-lived, with the show recently beaten i...

item.title: ‘I want to be there in tough times’: Eddie - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘I want to be there in tough times’: Eddie  The Advertiser

With coach Nathan Buckley’s far from secure and the Magpies out of finals contention at 6-10, there were calls on Wednesday morning for McGuire to move on as club president — a position he has held since the end of 1998. Essendon great Tim Watson questioned whether McGuire was “dealing with parts of the club that he shouldn’t be” and whether that would be one of the key findings of the current review of the Pies. But McGuire said he had never been more motivated to lead the club he has such passion for. “I’m actually, to be perfectly honest, in the most exciting phase of my career with what...

item.title: Odd Couple: Seeing red - The Advertiser
item.description:
Odd Couple: Seeing red  The Advertiser

1. DO the Bachar Houli and Tom Bugg incidents in consecutive weeks leave the AFL with no choice but to introduce a red card? Bugg cops 6 week ban Rooch: ON THE MONEY BUT with very, very strict guidelines. Umpires do get reports wrong – as West Coast proved with its appeal against Will Schofield’s one-game ban for striking Melbourne midfielder Clayton Oliver a fortnight ago. Clearly, there needs to be an immediate penalty for players who put an opponent out of the game. But there are risky reports here too, particularly with tackling – is it a reportable sling tackle that concussed a player ...

item.title: Eddie’s shock truths as Newman breaks silence - The Advertiser
item.description:
Eddie’s shock truths as Newman breaks silence  The Advertiser

It was revealed on Friday McGuire will co-host the program alongside Rebecca Maddern and Sam Newman, while Craig Hutchison has been axed. “The stars aligned literally in the last 24 hours,” McGuire said on ABC radio on Saturday. “There has been discussion over the last couple of months ... but ultimately I got the all clear on Thursday from Fox Footy. “Then yesterday all hell broke loose after Sam’s effort on Thursday night and from about 12.30-2.30 it was all systems go. “I didn’t have time to tell my wife until late in the afternoon.” While the move may have been finalised and announced h...

item.title: It’s now down to three - The Advertiser
item.description:
It’s now down to three  The Advertiser

Richmond are undefeated and sit second on the ladder while arguably the greatest team in the modern era, Hawthorn, are yet to win a game and Alastair Clarkson’s men find themselves dead last. The brutal season is a marathon and many storylines are yet playout but let’s look at the eight things we have learnt so far in 2017. 1 Only three teams can win the premiership flag. Adelaide are the most lethal side in the competition, but have they peaked too early? They are stingy in defence, move the ball faster than any other side and are potent when going inside 50. They should finish in the top ...

item.title: If the AFL is a 'leading' anti-racist organisation, why won't it address the racism I faced? - The Guardian
item.description:
If the AFL is a 'leading' anti-racist organisation, why won't it address the racism I faced?  The Guardian

I loved playing football. I gave 12 years of my life to playing the game professionally. But those years were also marked by the pain of being trapped in a culture that condoned racism through a combination of ignorance, habit, and arrogance. In the end, the message to a young, black man like me was clear: I was only of value if I didn’t challenge the status quo. In the past few weeks, I have re-lived the events that marked my final years of football. I have been repeatedly questioned about my experience – nine years of working in a culture where I was called “black cunt”, a “ni**er”, and a...

item.title: Nice one Eddie, but hard part is ahead - The Advertiser
item.description:
Nice one Eddie, but hard part is ahead  The Advertiser

Anyone who goes without food for a few weeks or more is guaranteed to lose weight. The hard thing is keeping the weight off once you go back to normal eating. The problem is that you haven’t adopted any new habits, or changed your lifestyle, which makes it much harder to maintain the weight loss long term. That is why I was surprised to see Collingwood president and TV and radio presenter Eddie McGuire openly discuss his extreme weight-loss methods. As this week’s SundayHerald Sun revealed, McGuire drank three cups of herb tonic a day in place of meals for two weeks. By the third week he in...

item.title: Host explodes: ‘Political whores’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Host explodes: ‘Political whores’  The Advertiser

Newman, who is never shy about letting his opinion be heard, claimed the AFL had “no right” to get involved in political messages and tell footy fans what to vote for. “Before I start this, I know it’s going to get hijacked (by) the predictable people who will say what it’s not,” he said. “But if this was about the AFL putting ‘yes’ on the football about climate change, or save the whales, or greenhouse emissions or whatever, I would have exactly the same opinion. The very fact it’s about the Yes vote for gay marriage is irrelevant, so please don’t hijack this into somethig it’s not. “But w...

item.title: Collingwood CEO Gary Pert quits - ABC News
item.description:
Collingwood CEO Gary Pert quits  ABC News

The long-time chief executive of Collingwood, Gary Pert, has announced his resignation, as a mid-season review of the club's underwhelming on-field performance continues. The former Fitzroy and Collingwood full-back has been in the role since 2007. Before that, he had a career in television and radio management. Coach Nathan Buckley is also under pressure to hold onto his job, with the Magpies sitting in 13th position on the AFL ladder after 18 rounds. Collingwood launched an extensive review of the club after another disappointing season on the field. Earlier this month, Pert addressed the...

item.title: Kyle Sandilands tells Eddie McGuire he's 135 kilos - The Australian
item.description:
Kyle Sandilands tells Eddie McGuire he's 135 kilos  The Australian

KIIS FM host Kyle Sandilands tells Eddie McGuire he's 135 kilos and needs help. Video: KIIS 1065 FM

item.title: Letters to the Editor, April 13 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Letters to the Editor, April 13  The Advertiser

SURELY the AFL and other sporting codes (male and female) would not be where they are today without the skill set of the many indigenous players within their applicable code. It is not just the indigenous players that make up a team, but the contribution from these wonderful sports people should not be overlooked. The player mix in the AFL nationally has many nations involved, and that has to be a blessing for the code. The judgment (if this is the correct word) of a player regardless of colour or religious background should be on their skillset and the contribution to their TEAM. Those tha...

item.title: Roos: I will not coach Collingwood - The Advertiser
item.description:
Roos: I will not coach Collingwood  The Advertiser

The former Sydney and Melbourne coach ended persistent rumours when he said today: “If I was asked to coach Collingwood, I would not coach Collingwood.” But Roos said he would be happy to sit down with Magpies president and Fox Footy colleague Eddie McGuire to discuss the Collingwood situation. LIVE COVERAGE: DEMONS PLAYING FOR A FINALS SPOT MATTHEW LLOYD: ‘BUCKLEY NEEDS SERIOUS HELP’ MARK ROBINSON: THE TOUGH CHOICE FACING EDDIE McGUIRE Collingwood is waiting on the completion of a strategic review of its football operations before making a call on Buckley after six years in the job. “I hav...

item.title: Eddie returns to The Footy Show - The Australian
item.description:
Eddie returns to The Footy Show  The Australian

McGuire, the president of the Collingwood Football Club and a former CEO of the Nine Network, got his big break in 1994 when he became host of the top-rating AFL talk show. He spent more than 10 years on the show, combining it with additional duties as host of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire before he replaced David Gyngell as the boss of Nine. The Herald Sun is reporting that journalist and presenter Craig Hutchison, who replaced James Brayshaw as host of The Footy Show, would step aside. However, it’s understood co-hosts Bec Maddern — who replaced Gary Lyon last year — and the ever-controve...

item.title: Houli will ’get booed mercilessly’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Houli will ’get booed mercilessly’  The Advertiser

AFL legend Matthews has backed the league appealing the defender’s two-match ban for knocking out Jed Lamb from Carlton, suggesting a penalty increase could save him from a harsh on-field crowd backlash. The AFL argued on Wednesday Houli’s ban was inadequate after its lawyers pushed for a four-match suspension at the previous evening’s hearing. JON RALPH: NOTHING WRONG WITH TIGERS’ HOULI DEFENCE MARK WILLIAMS: KIND, GENTLE HOULI ‘MADE A MISTAKE’ SUSPENSION: DOES HOULI’S TIME FIT THE CRIME? EDDIE MCGUIRE: ‘MOTHER TERESA WOULD GET FOUR WEEKS’ After receiving references from Prime Minister Mal...

item.title: Sam blasts ‘disgraceful, psychotic anarchists’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Sam blasts ‘disgraceful, psychotic anarchists’  The Advertiser

The AFL legend and Channel Nine Footy Show panellist was referring to a photo Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull posted at an AFL game, and he gave some other thought-provoking answers in an interview with former Labor leader Mark Latham on his program Mark Latham’s Outsiders this week. In the chat Newman addressed matters such as the AFL’s involvement in the same sex marriage debate, political correctness, whether the Footy Show is racist, Eddie McGuire’s dramas and what’s wrong with America. ON AFL’S INVOLVEMENT IN THE SAME SEX MARRIAGE DEBATE When told a rainbow flag was flying next to a Sw...

item.title: Eddie McGuire warns against rushing into BBL expansion - ABC News
item.description:
Eddie McGuire warns against rushing into BBL expansion  ABC News

Melbourne Stars president Eddie McGuire has cautioned against rushing into an expansion of the hugely successful Big Bash League. McGuire, who is also the chairman of AFL club Collingwood, said there is a risk of devaluing the competition by adding more teams too quickly. "I think we've got to hasten it slowly with this," McGuire told SEN radio. "I can understand everyone getting excited about it but, again, we've seen with the expansion of the AFL, it does bring its own issues. "We've got something pretty good at the moment and there's a few wrinkles we have to get sorted out before we get...

item.title: ‘Cause everyone’s team deserves to be seen’: Fox Footy promotes live offering for AFL season - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
‘Cause everyone’s team deserves to be seen’: Fox Footy promotes live offering for AFL season  mUmBRELLA*

Fox Sports’ Fox Footy channel is spruiking the live nature of their coverage of the AFL season in the lead up to the season launch in a new ad featuring AFL stars and president of the Collingwood Football Club Eddie McGuire. Created by TBWA Sydney, the ad shows a ‘staff member’ explaining how “every AFL fan deserves to see their team live,” while co-workers walk through the AFL banners of their preferred team which appear around the office. Fox Footy ‘staff’ and several male and female AFL figures are shown in the ad, as well as Eddie McGuire, while a voice-over explains the channel’s live...

item.title: Wil Anderson to return to air on Triple M’s Hot Breakfast - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Wil Anderson to return to air on Triple M’s Hot Breakfast  mUmBRELLA*

Comedian Wil Anderson is set to return to radio as a host on Triple M’s Hot Breakfast, joining Eddie McGuire and Luke Darcy. Anderson will be replacing Mick Molloy who departed the breakfast show in June to succeed Merrick Watts on Triple M drive with Jane Kennedy. Triple M’s Hot Breakfast hosts In 2001 Anderson co-hosted the Triple J breakfast radio show alongside Adam Spencer, departing the radio station in 2004. The executive producer and host of Gruen, is joining the third most popular breakfast show in Melbourne – according to Melbourne Radio Survey 5 – which has a 7.6% audience share....

item.title: Year in Review: June – Studio 10’s sex tape; Optus EPL backlash; Eddie McGuire’s apology - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Year in Review: June – Studio 10’s sex tape; Optus EPL backlash; Eddie McGuire’s apology  mUmBRELLA*

Studio 10 was reprimanded by the Australian Communications and Media Authority on the first day of June, after the show aired still images of actor Rob Lowe’s sex tape with an underage female. The ACMA ruled Ten breached the Code of Practice as the material was not in accordance with its PG classification. Following backlash on its decision to charge $15 per month to access the English Premier League, Optus announced it would offer free access to the EPL for new and existing subscribers. The company’s decision led to the reduction of a minimum spend for customers to get free access, from $8...

item.title: Newman’s bizarre Footy Show protest - The Advertiser
item.description:
Newman’s bizarre Footy Show protest  The Advertiser

The TV veteran appeared to be attempting to send a message by refusing to engage in conversation or bring his usual colourful edge to the program. The trainwreck began from the opening moments of the show as Newman was introduced but sat down without barely saying a word. “Cat got your tongue tonight has it?” host Craig Hutchison immediately asked. “No, get on with it,” Newman replied. Comedian David Hughes started trying to engage the former Geelong star, who typically offers his opinion on the big football topics of the week. There hasn’t been a bigger story than the resignations of AFL f...

item.title: Lyon: ‘Eddie needs to evaluate himself’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lyon: ‘Eddie needs to evaluate himself’  The Advertiser

The Magpies are 1-4 and as disappointing as their results have been, it’s their style of play and structure that have been most worrying to those in the footy world. A loss to Essendon on Anzac Day has further intensified the pressure on Buckley, who is facing an uphill battle to keep his job. But Lyon believes Collingwood president Eddie McGuire and CEO Gary Pert also need to examine their roles in what’s been a disappointing few years for the AFL’s biggest club. “They have to evaluate themselves too, they being Eddie McGuire and Gary Pert because they put this thing in place,” Lyon said o...

item.title: Magpies set to land Kangas footy chief - The Advertiser
item.description:
Magpies set to land Kangas footy chief  The Advertiser

It is understood the Magpies are close to finalising a ­replacement for Graeme Allan, who resigned from his short-lived stint after copping a one-year suspension for his role in the Lachie Whitfield affair. While the Magpies remain tight-lipped, Walsh is known to be the preferred candidate, even though he remains contracted to North Melbourne. He was going to take a lesser role with the Kangaroos next year after more than 30 years in the industry, handing over the head of football role to Cameron Joyce, but he was still going to work four days a week for the club. It would be a homecoming o...

item.title: Lumumba takes another swipe at Pies - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lumumba takes another swipe at Pies  The Advertiser

Lumumba’s new SBS documentary accuses Collingwood player of using the nickname “chimp” to describe him for much of his career at the club. He posted on his Facebook page today that his concerns had been swept under the carpet by Collingwood. And he said the AFL and Collingwood should have penalised Eddie McGuire for his “ape” comments against Adam Goodes. He is also frustrated by the silence from the AFL and AFLPA over his concerns. He said today teammates like American ruckman Shae McNamara and Leon Davis had confirmed the racism that existed at the club. The Pies have painted Lumumba’s co...

item.title: Eddie Everywhere somewhere else? - The Australian
item.description:
Eddie Everywhere somewhere else?  The Australian

Collingwood’s women’s team was part of history on Friday night, taking on Carlton in the first game in the new AFL Women’s competition. Almost 25,000 fans were there to see it, with a couple of thousand more turned away when Princes Park reached capacity. And more than one million people watched it on TV. The one person you would expect to be there, showing his support for Collingwood players at such a significant time, was not. Eddie Everywhere was somewhere else — in another city in fact. McGuire was in Adelaide anchoring the television coverage of the Danny Green-Anthony Mundine fight. C...

item.title: Pies chief: ‘my time was up’ - The Australian
item.description:
Pies chief: ‘my time was up’  The Australian

Pert revealed his plans at a media conference with club president Eddie McGuire, ending a 10-year stint in the role. Peter Murphy, who is conducting a review into the Pies’ on and off-field operations, will act as interim CEO until a permanent replacement is found. Pert said he could not commit to the club long-term. “I asked him (Murphy) to put a different set of eyes on the club and start thinking about what the club looks like in the future,” Pert said. “(I needed to ask) ‘am I actually going to be the one that’s leading that?’ and if I’m not, I need to go to the board and say, ‘my time’...

item.title: Eddie McGuire gunned by radio host - The Advertiser
item.description:
Eddie McGuire gunned by radio host  The Advertiser

McGuire did not attend the inaugural AFL Women’s match between Carlton and Collingwood on Friday night at Princes Park in Melbourne. McGuire’s failure to attend the historic moment in the history of his football club and women’s sport in Australia has been met with staunch criticism from media commentators and football figures. More than 24,500 fans attended the AFL Women’s season opener. Channel 10 personality and Sydney radio star Amanda Keller said McGuire’s no-show casts him in a poor light. “This was the first weekend of the AFL women’s competition and it was massive,” Keller said on W...

item.title: In defence of my mate Eddie - The Australian
item.description:
In defence of my mate Eddie  The Australian

But at day’s end, Eddie is my mate and I don’t like it when he is unfairly beaten up like he has been since Friday night. Eddie hosted the Mundine-Green fight on Foxtel instead of attending the first ever AFL women’s competition match between Collingwood and Carlton. I asked him back in November, maybe early December, to host the fight broadcast because it was a massive deal for Foxtel, one of the biggest broadcasts ever undertaken. We were getting the best people together and he’s the best host there is in sports. At that time the historic Collingwood v Carlton women’s opener was scheduled...

item.title: Eddie rejects Footy Show gay reveal rumour - The Advertiser
item.description:
Eddie rejects Footy Show gay reveal rumour  The Advertiser

McGuire is back hosting the program following Craig Hutchison’s sacking nearly three weeks ago and Thursday night will be his first appearance in the hot seat since his return was announced. McGuire has promised to bring plenty of changes to the show whose ratings have suffered in the face of fresh competition from Channel Seven’s AFL program The Front Bar. In response to what McGuire says is “internet rumour and innuendo”, he assured Australia the AFL’s first openly gay player would not be revealing themselves on the show this week. “I can tell you that is absolute nonsense. No, that’s not...

item.title: Triple M pushes sport, music and comedy in re-brand campaign that says ‘There’s only one’ - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Triple M pushes sport, music and comedy in re-brand campaign that says ‘There’s only one’  mUmBRELLA*

Triple M has launched a new campaign for its metro stations as part of its rebrand, celebrating Australian sportsmen, rockstars and comedians. (L-R): Rampaging Roy Slaven and HG Nelson front the campaign. The latest work promotes the the on-air talent with familiar faces of Triple M while also highlighting the networks growing focus on sport to position the brand as ‘the one station’ for Australian rock, sport and comedy. Triple M’s new work includes Chris Judd, Wendell Sailor, Peter Sterling, Jimmy Barnes, The Living End, Ryan Girdler, Tony Squires, Billy Brownless, Wayne Carey, Merrick W...

item.title: 'Lay a wreath' for Lou Richards, Collingwood president Eddie McGuire says - ABC News
item.description:
'Lay a wreath' for Lou Richards, Collingwood president Eddie McGuire says  ABC News

The AFL community is remembering former Collingwood captain Lou Richards as a pioneer for Australian Rules football, opening up media careers to modern footballers and introducing the sport to new audiences with his "panache". Lou Richards, also known as "Louie the Lip", died at the age of 94 today. Richards followed his 14-year playing career with a decades long career in television, radio and newspaper, most notably on the long-running World of Sport and League Teams, with Richmond legend Jack Dyer and Geelong star Bob Davis. The shows combined football and entertainment for the first tim...

item.title: ‘I tried to suport him as best I could’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘I tried to suport him as best I could’  The Advertiser

In a documentary on Lumumba titled Fair Game Lumumba describes Collingwood as a “boys’ club for racist and sexist jokes” and accuses Buckley of lacking “emotional intelligence”. The Pies’ 2010 premiership player also said his stand against president Eddie McGuire’s 2013 racist radio joke towards Adam Goodes ultimately led to his departure from the club. HEADLINES: A HISTORY OF STRANGE LUMUMBA INTERVIEWS “It’s a bit sad in many ways that ‘H’ feels that way about his experiences in the game and he’s been a great contributor to our footy club for a decade and 199 games and I shared those times...

item.title: ‘We won’t turn on our own’: Eddie’s ardent spiel - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘We won’t turn on our own’: Eddie’s ardent spiel  The Advertiser

And McGuire has also passionately defended embattled coach Nathan Buckley, saying there is “no better person” to be sitting in the coaching hot seat. McGuire’s extraordinary rev-up came after Collingwood’s disappointing performances against Essendon on Anzac Day, which saw the Pies go down by 18 points despite having 23 more inside 50s than the Bombers in the match. The Pies have now slumped to 13th on the ladder with a 1-4 record in a season Buckley said they had to make finals, otherwise “there’s no way” he would keep his job. KING: FROM NOW, IT’S ABOUT MANAGING BUCKS’ EXIT But McGuire on...

item.title: James is home on the ranges - The Advertiser
item.description:
James is home on the ranges  The Advertiser

The couple shared photos of their week-long road trip around the state on social media, with four of their children from previous relationships coming along for the ride. James, 50, who played cricket for South Australia and lived here for many years with ex-wife Sarah, couldn’t speak highly enough of the region as they stopped in at The Arkaroola Resort and Wilderness Sanctuary, hiked at Wilpena Pound and enjoyed the local hospitality at the Renmark and Cradock Hotels. “First hike done ... kids thought they were gonna perish Burke & Wills style!!! This place is really cool!!!,” he captione...

item.title: ‘Sportsman’s night, not a funeral’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘Sportsman’s night, not a funeral’  The Australian

The Collingwood champion, who died last Monday aged 94, would be the only person capable of “turning a state service into a sportsman’s night”, Richards’ close friend and journalist Tony Jones said. Richards was honoured today with a state funeral at St Paul’s Cathedral, a service attended by the biggest names in football and media. Lou Richards gallery Among them were Ron Barassi, triple-Brownlow Medallist Bob Skilton and Kevin Sheedy, Collingwood legends Des Tuddenham and Peter McKenna, current coach and Team of the Century member Nathan Buckley. Outside St Paul’s, hundreds of people gath...

item.title: 'I don't get paid to do this': Eddie McGuire hits back at Collingwood critics - The Guardian
item.description:
'I don't get paid to do this': Eddie McGuire hits back at Collingwood critics  The Guardian

Collingwood president Eddie McGuire has emphatically rejected claims he should stand down from his position with the struggling club, claiming he has never been more excited by the prospect of reviving the Pies’ fortunes, but admits the club needs a new blueprint for the future following its recent on-field woes. Reacting to media speculation that the club had become stale and needed fresh ideas, McGuire said he had never felt more energised to take the club into a new era. “I’m not trying to gild the lily. I’m actually, to be perfectly honest, in the most exciting phase of my career with w...

item.title: Eddie’s empire crumbling around him - The Advertiser
item.description:
Eddie’s empire crumbling around him  The Advertiser

Channel Seven reports the one-time All-Australian-turned-administrator is leaving as part of a wideranging review into the powerhouse club’s underperformance. It remains to be seen whether out-of-contract coach Nathan Buckley will be retained next season after leading his side to seven wins in 17 games so far in 2017. Gary Pert, who played 233 games for Fitzroy and Collingwood from 1982-95, joined the Magpies midway through 2007. Before taking over the Magpies job he was managing director of Channel 9 and radio network Austereo. Club president Eddie McGuire and Pert will front the media at ...

item.title: Pert to leave Pies after 10 years - The Advertiser
item.description:
Pert to leave Pies after 10 years  The Advertiser

Pert, who joined the Magpies a decade ago, will announce his decision this afternoon. ANALYSIS: PIES CALL FOR STRATEGIC REVIEW BUCKS SAFE: PERT’S MEETING WITH PLAYERS ROBBO: TIME FOR EDDIE TO MOVE ON? The Pies have called a press conference for 2pm at their headquarters, where Pert and club president Eddie McGuire will front the media. Pert’s decision to stand down comes amid a wideranging review of the football club. Senior coach Nathan Buckley’s future has been a constant source of speculation throughout 2017, while McGuire has also rebutted calls for him to stand down should the coach de...

item.title: Nathan Buckley’s future decided - The Advertiser
item.description:
Nathan Buckley’s future decided  The Advertiser

The Magpies have called a media conference for 10.30am AEST where president Eddie McGuire will make an announcement. Buckley has been at the helm since 2012 and has been under immense pressure this season with his team finishing 13th on the ladder, having not made the finals since 2013. McGuire will be joined at the media conference by Magpies football boss Geoff Walsh and Buckley. “I said to everybody four months ago that Collingwood was having a full review into its entire operations, including the board, administration and football department,” said McGuire on Triple M on Monday. “There ...

item.title: What did Selwood say to Pendles? - The Advertiser
item.description:
What did Selwood say to Pendles?  The Advertiser

Nothing too dramatic. Nothing coach Chris Scott will question him about. And probably half of his team didn’t see it, anyway. But the problem was all of the footy world saw it. THE TACKLE: MAGPIES DAZZLE, HAWKS STINK The Geelong captain allowed his competitive fibres to stray into the uncompetitive zone when he and Collingwood captain Scott Pendlebury spoke on the ground after the final siren on Sunday. We only have footage and it showed Selwood talking to a bewildered-looking Pendlebury. There’s an awkward handshake before Selwood keeps talking and then they separate. It was unusual becaus...

item.title: Playboy saved Sam Newman’s life - The Advertiser
item.description:
Playboy saved Sam Newman’s life  The Advertiser

He’d been working for a transport company in the 1980s when a business partner asked him to guarantee a bank loan. The company went bust, Newman lost $400,000 and his house — and he was forced to start sleeping in the back of friend’s shop. As he tells Mark Howard in the latest episode of his podcast series The Howie Games, he was “stone, motherless broke”. “I’d played football and had a pretty good business and had a pretty good life then all of a sudden I had absolutely nothing,” Newman says. But a Playboy magazine changed everything. The former footy star — who retired in 1980 after play...

item.title: ‘It’s not back to the future’: Eddie McGuire returns for the ‘rebirth’ of Nine’s AFL Footy Show - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
‘It’s not back to the future’: Eddie McGuire returns for the ‘rebirth’ of Nine’s AFL Footy Show  mUmBRELLA*

Despite flicking the bird on air last night, Sam Newman will remain a host of Nine’s AFL Footy Show, and will be reunited with Eddie McGuire who returns to the show after an 11 year absence. McGuire will join Newman and co-host Rebecca Maddern, with Craig Hutchinson exiting after a four month stint as the once dominant show struggles against Seven’s competing Front Bar program. McGuire and Maddern addressed the media this afternoon. Commenting on his return, McGuire told the media in a live stream on 9news.com.au: “To come back with Bec, who’s dominating so much with Ninja at the moment, an...

item.title: Wil Anderson replaces Mick Molloy - The Advertiser
item.description:
Wil Anderson replaces Mick Molloy  The Advertiser

Anderson, who also hosts Gruen on ABC-TV, replaces funnyman Mick Molloy who is moving to a national drive show with Jane Kennedy. Anderson said: “I am a huge fan of the (Hot Breakfast) show. It’s been my lifeline to Melbourne as I have toured the world doing stand-up. I’m guessing I’ve probably heard more of it than Mick has. “It’s a show that gives you the news, and makes the news, all with a laugh. So many times I have thought I would love to be part of that conversation, and now I’m rapt that get to, waking up with my favourite city in the world.” On replacing Molloy, Anderson said: “The...

item.title: Magpies continue to go backwards - The Advertiser
item.description:
Magpies continue to go backwards  The Advertiser

Adelaide? No longer are the Crows considered invincible. And for the first time, coach Don Pyke has had major criticism of his work. Emotion always gets the better of FIVEaa commentator Stephen Rowe, but there will be an echo to his quarter-time analysis that Pyke had “a touch of the Neil Craigs” by not reacting during North Melbourne’s unanswered 10-goal first term in Hobart. Port Adelaide? The Power had so much of the ball and so little method in attack against West Coast at Adelaide Oval. As with the Crows last year, this home loss to the Eagles could cost Ken Hinkley’s group a double-ch...

item.title: Live: Hidden impact of AFL scandal - The Advertiser
item.description:
Live: Hidden impact of AFL scandal  The Advertiser

Welcome to AFL Saturday, our coverage of today’s games: Geelong vs. Hawthorn Port Adelaide vs. North Melbourne Collingwood vs. Gold Coast Greater Western Sydney vs. Sydney Adelaide vs. Melbourne WELCOME to AFL Saturday. Five big matches — highlighted by a huge Sydney derby — greet you this afternoon. St Kilda were rocked last night by a plucky Essendon side, falling disastrously behind in a 17.16 (118) — 7.15 (57) loss to the Bombers. Their damning capitulation came after a huge performance in the last round to destroy the Tigers in a 67-point thrashing. Third-placed Geelong kick off the af...

item.title: The AFL’s biggest feuds - The Advertiser
item.description:
The AFL’s biggest feuds  The Advertiser

SCROLL DOWN FOR THE FULL LIST AND TO VOTE 1. ANDREW DEMETRIOU v JAMES HIRD Hatred is a term that doesn’t come close to quantifying the toxic level of anger between these two. So many relationships were rived in two by the ASADA saga, but this was a three-year running battle from which neither escaped. After Essendon “self-reported” in February 2013 Hird had reason to believe the AFL was leaking extensively about the Essendon investigation. After holding his tongue for several months Hird decided to hit back, as the AFL’s dealings on the “night of crisis” became a parallel scandal. “I’ve tol...

item.title: This has just got worse for Buckley - The Advertiser
item.description:
This has just got worse for Buckley  The Advertiser

The Pies are 1-4, almost certainly won’t play finals and unless there is a drastic change in performance, either Collingwood coach Nathan Buckley or president Eddie McGuire will have to make a tough decision at the end of the year — if not earlier. One loss doesn’t ruin a career but a loss on a solemn afternoon against an old foe, when questions are asked once again about consistency of effort and intensity and execution hurts the long-term plans. Buckley’s coaching adventure is like a game of eeny, meeny, miny, moe. The Pies jump into the fire and jump out; they jump back in and can’t get ...

item.title: Fresh blow hits Eddie where it hurts most - The Advertiser
item.description:
Fresh blow hits Eddie where it hurts most  The Advertiser

The Pies president has been at the helm of Australia’s biggest football club for nearly two decades. He’s ridden every high and every low — his passion evident in his animated reactions whenever TV cameras capture him in the stands or on the ground watching his team play. After Collingwood’s comeback 13.15 (93) to 13.7 (85) win over West Coast on Sunday, McGuire was down in the race chanting with supporters. It’s a sight we’ve become accustomed to seeing over the years. But will there be fewer voices to sing with from now on? In a damning slight on Collingwood’s status in the footy world, j...

item.title: Eddie ready for rebuild - The Australian
item.description:
Eddie ready for rebuild  The Australian

It was the 2010 preliminary final and Eddie McGuire’s team was on its way to a 41-point win over Geelong and a place in two grand finals. They drew the following week with St Kilda but won the premiership in the replay the following week. Collingwo-od. It was a unique — unforgettable — moment in AFL football. McGuire, the president of Collingwood, looked about the league and club officials, the politicians and hoi polloi who surrounded him. They had devoured their lunch and drunk the wine. Many smiled, some signalled congratulations. “But I can remember seeing hate in the eyes of some,” McG...

item.title: Wells critical to Buckley’s future - The Australian
item.description:
Wells critical to Buckley’s future  The Australian

As Buckley fights for his own future, it’s evident the former North Melbourne star has become critically important to the Collingwood’s coach’s hopes of extending his tenure. Wells is coming off one of the best matches of his career: the 32-year-old kicked three goals from 34 possessions in the draw against the top-placed Adelaide last Sunday. As the Magpies slipped from ­finals contention and the pressure mounted on Buckley, the coach ­lamented a disconnect between his midfield and forward line. The exquisitely skilled Wells has provided the solution. His decision-making and use of the bal...

item.title: Footy world farewells Lou the legend - The Advertiser
item.description:
Footy world farewells Lou the legend  The Advertiser

The Collingwood legend died on May 8 at a Melbourne nursing home, aged 94 after more than 70 years in the public eye. Those unable to squeeze into a packed St Paul’s Cathedral gathered at nearby Federation Square where the service was screened live. Scroll below to relive our coverage of the service Some of footy’s best-known faces including Collingwood President Eddie McGuire, AFL chief executive Gill McLachlan, Ron Barassi and Kevin Sheedy attended along with Magpie greats such as Peter McKenna and Des Tuddenham (scroll below to read their quotes). Lou’s great mate Ron Joseph spoke at the...

item.title: ‘He’ll regret it, ridiculous thing to say’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘He’ll regret it, ridiculous thing to say’  The Advertiser

Welcome to AFL Saturday, our coverage of today’s games: GWS vs Melbourne, 1.45pm Essendon vs Carlton, 2.10pm Brisbane vs Western Bulldogs, 4.35pm North Melbourne vs Collingwood, 7.25pm Fremantle vs Gold Coast, 7.40pm (AEST) EVERY game is a must-win for sides looking to cement a spot in the top eight as the season draws to a close. Melbourne has been inconsistent of late but can strengthen its finals push with a win over GWS, who finally recorded a victory last week after two draws and two losses. Essendon can also move up from 10th if it defeats 17th-placed Carlton and other results go the ...

item.title: Gangster wrap for Adelaide turf - The Advertiser
item.description:
Gangster wrap for Adelaide turf  The Advertiser

Melbounre underworld identity Mick Gatto said he was excited about his first visit to the Oval to see two of his friends settle Australian boxing’s biggest feud. “I’m quite friendly with both of them (so) I’d love to see a draw but it’ll be interesting. It’s a going to be a good night,” Gatto, who now works as an industrial dispute mediator. “It’s a beautiful city, nice and quiet. I might look for a bit of property and move up here,” he said. “It’s great, nice and laid back.” Gatto, a former member of the so-called “Carlton Crew” and acquitted of the 2005 murder of hit-man Andrew “Benji” Ve...

item.title: Louie the Lip blazed a trail - The Advertiser
item.description:
Louie the Lip blazed a trail  The Advertiser

The Collingwood great loved a laugh and it was that sense of fun which turned him into a TV and media superstar. Whether he was calling matches, sitting on a football panel, or handing out Bertocchi hams, Richards found a way to captivate audiences. “Lou was a star on AM radio, FM radio, black and white as well as colour television and even film with The Club — such was his crossover appeal,” Eddie McGuire said. Richards’ newspaper columns for the Sun News-Pictorial quickly earned him the nickname “Louie the Lip”. He called the football alongside Ron Casey on radio’s 3DB and in 1959 joined ...

item.title: Magpies to undergo external review - The Advertiser
item.description:
Magpies to undergo external review  The Advertiser

The Magpies have appointed experienced businessman Peter Murphy to lead the examination of every department, including the men’s and women’s football set-ups and netball division. The “strategic blueprint” could form part of the end-of-season analysis of Collingwood’s coaching staff, including out-of-contract senior coach Nathan Buckley. MENTAL HEALTH: FASOLO SEEKS HELP FOR DEPRESSION OWN GOALS: MAGPIES CAN REMEDY ACCURACY WOES President Eddie McGuire said the review would provide clear guidance on how the club could continue to grow over the next decade and specifically combat the league’s...

item.title: Newman’s bizarre rant: ‘This country is rooted’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Newman’s bizarre rant: ‘This country is rooted’  The Advertiser

And this time, the controversial 71-year-old may have outdone himself. Newman made headlines in July after making an on-air statement in the direction of Channel Nine, sitting in silence before raising his middle finger to the camera. But this effort on Thursday night’s Footy Show was slightly more political, taking aim at the latest controversy surrounding Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull. The Liberal Party leader was taken to the cleaners after posting a photo of himself at the footy while holding his grandchild in one arm and a beer in the other. “Does anyone see anything irresponsible wi...

item.title: Sam off the leash in bizarre radio rants - The Advertiser
item.description:
Sam off the leash in bizarre radio rants  The Advertiser

Newman also takes swipe at former US president Barack Obama, praises current president Donald Trump and insists he’ll be sober for the return of the revamped format on Channel 9. Newman asked Triple M’s Hot Breakfast host Eddie McGuire — who is also returning to the show — whether Maddern will be there. “Is Rebecca still on the set or have we bounced back from her?” he asked. SNEAK PEEK AT WHAT’S PLANNED FOR NEW-LOOK FOOTY SHOW McGuire said: “We’ve got a spot for her in the carpark and we’ll cross to her.” As the interview wraps up a determined Newman revisits the topic, before McGuire assu...

item.title: Hutchy opens up on Eddie power play - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hutchy opens up on Eddie power play  The Advertiser

Welcome to AFL Saturday, our coverage of today’s matches: Essendon v North Melbourne, 1.45pm (AEST) Melbourne v Port Adelaide, 2.10pm Western Bulldogs v Gold Coast, 4.35pm Sydney v St Kilda, 7.25pm Fremantle v Hawthorn, 7.40pm SEX scandals, social media abuse and a huge shake-up of the Footy Show have dominated the week of AFL. Attention returned to the field as the Crows edged the Cats in a top-of-the-table clash on Friday night and there’s top eight implications involved in all five games on Saturday if you still believe Freo and Hawthorn are capable of making a run. Essendon is also in a...

item.title: Eddie is ‘not going anywhere’ - The Australian
item.description:
Eddie is ‘not going anywhere’  The Australian

As Collingwood head towards a fourth straight September without finals football, Magpies president Eddie McGuire insists he still has the passion to lead the biggest club in the AFL. Like under-fire coach Nathan Buckley, McGuire has come in for criticism over the club’s on-field downturn. McGuire combines his unpaid club duties with one of the most prolific schedules in Australian media. He was first elected as president in 1998, and says he’ll answer to the voting public — Collingwood members — rather than the media. “The only people I have to stand to are the Collingwood members who voted...

item.title: Pops: ‘Someone’s car is getting egged’ - The Advertiser
item.description:
Pops: ‘Someone’s car is getting egged’  The Advertiser

Every weekday we will be bringing you all the breaking footy news from across Australia as it happens. The big news today is The Footy Show’s return. We’ll have all the reax today from a big night in footy. TRIM EDDIE: HOW MCGUIRE LOST WEIGHT FOR FOOTY SHOW RETURN We will be providing rolling news as it happens and giving you all the latest insights from our experts around the country. Whoever you support, there is only one place to be.

item.title: Lou’s service bigger than Texas - The Australian
item.description:
Lou’s service bigger than Texas  The Australian

It was a larger-than-life boast by “Louie the Lip”, the Collingwood captain and television icon who became exactly that — a character far bigger and bolder than his stature. The claim may have been exaggerated as much as the outlandish nicknames he gave to footballers, but as proved yesterday at Richards’s state funeral, he was not far wrong. A hall of fame of football and media identities joined family and friends at a service in St Paul’s Cathedr­al in Melbourne honouring Collingwood’s 1953 premiership captain, who died last week aged 94. Among them were Ron Barassi, triple Brownlow medal...

item.title: Ratings send shockwaves through SEN - The Advertiser
item.description:
Ratings send shockwaves through SEN  The Advertiser

Although the SEN team started a couple of weeks later then the rest of the breakfast crew in Melbourne on January 30 — the early figures aren’t encouraging. SEN breakfast dropped from a 3.8 share to a 2.5 share, despite all the publicity surrounding Lyon’s return to radio. AFL Daily! Live rolling footy news from around Australia The SEN team were beaten by Radio National, 3JJJ and ABCFM — which plays classical music. SEN will be hoping with the start of the AFL footy season upon us, the figures will pick up and their huge investment in the breakfast team will start to pay off. All eyes will...
